                                                    </h3>
                                                
                                                
                                                    <p class="cmp-profile-promo__content__bio">
                                                        Rosemary is a specialist executive in Deloitte Consulting LLP’s Government & Public Services (GPS) practice. Prior to joining Deloitte, Rosemary served as deputy assistant secretary of defense for Military Community & Family Policy where she received the Secretary of Defense Exceptional Civilian Service medal, and as assistant secretary of Veterans Affairs for Public & Intergovernmental Affairs. She also represented military families at the National Alliance for Suicide Prevention on behalf of the federal government and as agency representative to the White House Council on Military Families. Rosemary’s work with military families and veterans follows a broadcast journalism career, during which she received numerous awards including a National Emmy Award for Team Coverage of the attacks on September 11th as Executive Producer at MSNBC. She has written on mental health and military families and is author of Maritime Annapolis – A History of Waterman, Sails & Midshipmen.

<div class="aem-Grid aem-Grid--12 aem-Grid--default--12 ">
    
    <div class="text cmp-standard-rte--60-width aem-GridColumn aem-GridColumn--default--12">
<div class="cmp-text">
    <h3><a id="meeting-the"></a>Meeting the moment</h3>
<p><i></i>During the initial tumultuous months of 2020, as communities around the country—and the world—retreated into quarantine due to the pandemic, the Veterans Health Administration (VHA) tackled unforeseen challenges almost daily, including national personal protective equipment (PPE) supply strain; the infection, and in some cases, deaths of frontline clinicians; and a presidential mandate to support the national response to COVID-19.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-1" href="#endnote-1">1</a></sup></p>
<p>This was all in almost real time, in addition to suddenly providing care to the millions of Veterans they already served via telemedicine. Department of Veteran Affairs (VA) employees, as with the rest of the nation, were flooded with emotions—fear, uncertainty, loneliness, anger, grief, and conversely, at times, hope and pride.</p>
<p>Eventually, it became clear to the VHA leadership: Success was all about trust. Specifically, VHA’s actions and communication needed to assure VA employees that PPE supplies were arriving, that it was safe for Veterans and their families to come to VA’s medical facilities for care, and that all Veterans—regardless of race, ethnicity, or socioeconomic background, could get the best care anywhere at VA.</p>
<p>More practically speaking, the response required sharing the information people needed most quickly and transparently in an ever-changing and often politically charged environment. It was about demonstrating empathy. Within weeks, communication and trust became the single integral element that powered VA’s response to the pandemic both internally and externally.</p>
<p>And these were challenging times not just because of the pandemic. Trust in government was at historic lows.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-2" href="#endnote-2">2</a></sup> Communicating in such a trust-deficit environment can be extremely challenging.</p>

</div>

    

</div>
<div class="pagenavigation cmp-nav--title-image cmp-nav--title-image--40-width cmp--float-right cmp--width-40 aem-GridColumn aem-GridColumn--default--12">


  
  <div class="cmp-nav">
    <div class="cmp-nav__container">
      
        <strong class="cmp-nav__title">Learn more</strong>

<div class="text cmp-standard-rte--60-width aem-GridColumn aem-GridColumn--default--12">
<div class="cmp-text">
    <p>With the focus now on building trust, the VHA team designed a communications strategy focused on three elements: competency, humanity, and integrity.</p>
<ul><li><b>Competency:</b> Internal and external stakeholders needed to know that VHA was good at health care delivery—an authority in the field—and that its operations and staff were capable, logical, and of high quality.</li><li><b>Humanity:</b> Veterans, employees, and their families wanted to know that leaders saw them and understood them beyond a job title or a statistic. It was important to demonstrate that the leadership’s decisions were made with genuine empathy, care, and concern, even when the decisions were not welcomed, such as limiting family visits to those in in-patient and community living center units.</li><li><b>Integrity:</b> It had been over 100 years since the nation faced such a massive health crisis so no organization was prepared, and more information was being discovered about the disease daily. Stakeholders wanted VHA to be agile and fully transparent in its approach, especially as guidance shifted. Leaders could not be seen as clinging to previous decisions or policies that were overcome by events.</li></ul>
<p>The VHA’s 360,000 employees went on to not only save lives within the VA health care system, but also complete more than 150 missions with Federal Emergency Management Agency as part of the national response, administering millions of vaccinations, and opening doors to non-enrolled Veterans, spouses, caregivers, and communities across the nation.</p>
<p>This study explores how leaders can tap into the three elements of trust—competence, humanity, and integrity—to effectively break through in today’s trust-deficit environment.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-3" href="#endnote-3">3</a></sup> To meet these needs organizations should design small, agile, cross-functional “rapid response” teams to specifically address the important intersection of communication and trust.</p>
<p>These rapid response communication teams should engage not only in the business of facts and messaging but also the areas of psychology, mental health, and social awareness. By focusing on establishing empathy and trust from both leaders and institutions, taking advantage of the skills of a behavioral health specialist, and combining their expertise with effective social listening and graphic design, organizations can structure not just the words used but also the nonverbal and emotional communication that invites and builds trust and gives a message sticking power.</p>
<h3><a id="rapid-response"></a>From crisis communication to “rapid response”</h3>
<p>The foundational redesign of VHA’s communication strategy started before the pandemic in 2020. In the fall of 2019, the VHA decided to reimagine its communication strategy and engaged a team to augment its existing capabilities. The team worked on moving away from traditional crisis communications to a “rapid response” approach, signaling a shift from the old respond-and-defend mode to being proactive and strategic. Specifically, the team provided forward-looking surge support to internal leaders and their communication teams by anticipating bad news and formulating a communication plan.</p>
<p>Because the team’s emphasis was on building trust through agility and responsiveness, it was designed to be kept to a core group of three: an executive strategist, a senior executive writer, and a behavioral health communication specialist. The team also consisted of visual design specialists, misinformation experts, and video production specialists. These teams addressed trust by understanding the practices outside of the communication wheelhouse, including conflict resolution, online information patterns, social media networks, mental health, sociology, linguistics, and beyond (figure 1). Professionals in many of these disciplines have been examining and designing for trust for decades and offered meaningful insights to communicators about navigating the realities of the communication environment quickly and effectively.</p>

</div>

    

</div>

<div class="text aem-GridColumn aem-GridColumn--default--12">
<div class="cmp-text">
    <p>The creation of the rapid response communication team was an important decision in hindsight. As the pandemic hit American shores in early 2020, the VHA communication team was ready to respond to the incoming crisis. Within days, the team mapped the three elements of trust into an agile and responsive content strategy for regular communication with employees and external stakeholders. The new communication strategy was centered on a recently launched daily video message delivered by the executive in charge of VHA, retired Army Major General Dr. Richard Stone, who was responsible for answering myriad questions for his 360,000+ employees.</p>
<p>Some videos were operational, sharing information, and building on competency. Others were a behind-the-scenes look at decision-making filmed in locations most employees would never see, demonstrating integrity. Stone also shared stories that viewers could relate with, including his time serving in Afghanistan as a combat doctor, his childhood growing up in Michigan, his children, and his concern for his aging father. The employees now saw the “human” side of their spokesperson and leader facing many of the same emotions and challenges that they were facing.</p>
<p>These videos were just two to three minutes long, with Stone speaking directly into a cellphone camera without notes. They were filmed in the early morning in his office and released to employees later that same day. Almost instantaneously, VA’s large workforce had a direct line to communication with its leader.</p>
<p>In addition to seeing and hearing their leaders in their own words, the communication strategy called for employees to also receive written guidance and encouragement in close to real time. Speaking with one voice, Dr. Stone and his team didn’t deny the uncertainty about the future and fear that the pandemic would endanger loved ones. Instead, they stood in the moment with their employees, honoring their experiences, being empathetic to their challenges, and giving assurance through connection and commitment.</p>
<p>The response from VHA employees was overwhelmingly positive and quickly created a feedback loop. Tens of thousands viewed the videos every day and wrote back about how the messages “reminded them that they are not alone in this fight,” “inspired them,” “provided them strength,” “were a fine balance between encouragement and acknowledgment of fear,” and “provided them a peek into leadership decision-making.” Some of the feedback informed the communication strategy with key messages and personal stories from the field.</p>
<p>Importantly, the trust-based communication strategy was backed by concrete actions that showed agility and competence in tackling the health crisis. This was important to ensure that the leadership “walked the walk”—that their actions matched their words. For instance, the agency’s investments in cloud technology allowed it to scale quickly to address the demand for telehealth, telework, veteran communications, and later for vaccination scheduling and tracking. Remote connections capacity tripled from 59,000 to 127,000 unique daily users between February and June 2020.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-4" href="#endnote-4">4</a></sup></p>
<p>The story of VHA during the pandemic shows the importance and impact of honest, empathetic, transparent communication from leaders during times of crisis. Government leaders today can face cumbersome processes to get information to their networks and challenging tensions when delivering complex messages. It is not just in crisis communication, however, that trust communication strategies are necessary. Trust is important for successful missions across the US government at all levels.</p>
<h3><a id="three-elements"></a>Leveraging the three elements of trust</h3>
<p>As traditional and social media become more deeply connected and woven into the fabric of our lives, government communication needs to move beyond just traditional press releases. News moves at the speed of light in today’s media. A new public policy draft sent to leadership for feedback before its scheduled release will be forwarded, posted, and discussed on the local or national evening news by the end of the day. Confidentiality may not always be guaranteed.</p>
<p>As governments explore ways to communicate in this complex and ever-evolving environment, they can be supported by communication strategies and teams that tap into and leverage the three elements of trust (figure 2). However, communication needs to accurately reflect the reality on the ground and be followed by transparent and logical actions that drive the three elements of trust.</p>

</div>

    

</div>

<div class="text aem-GridColumn aem-GridColumn--default--12">
<div class="cmp-text">
    <h4>Competency</h4>
<p>Competency refers to the capacity and resources required to successfully achieve current and future actions—the ability to do what you say you will do. In the VHA’s case, it was visible in Dr. Stone’s focus on operational capabilities, reducing administrative barriers, frontline response, and providing information on therapeutics which underlined the agency’s competence in battling the pandemic.</p>
<p>His confidence in the competency of his employees was also a constant refrain. And this confidence was supported by data; Veterans’ trust in VA had consistently improved since 2016 and their regularly measured trust score was between 70% and 75% when the pandemic hit in early 2020.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-5" href="#endnote-5">5</a></sup> He consistently reiterated his belief that those closest to the bedside knew best, and demonstrated his unwavering trust and respect for his employees.</p>
<p>Taiwan offers another example of the role of competency in building trust. The Taiwan Central Epidemic Command Center (CECC) played a critical part in not only communicating effectively during the pandemic but also taking actions to reassure residents.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-6" href="#endnote-6">6</a></sup> The CECC’s daily live-streamed press conferences provided residents with important information on health screenings, city restrictions, mask stockpiles in pharmacies, and other public health protocols.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-7" href="#endnote-7">7</a></sup> These communications were accompanied by actions on the ground.</p>
<p>As early as December 2019, Taiwan medical officers snapped into action based on early accounts of a potential virus spread in China. The country activated its public health protocols put in place during the 2003 SARS outbreak to put early travel restrictions, health screening for people traveling from China, and shoring up mask production by deploying military personnel.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-8" href="#endnote-8">8</a></sup> In addition to demonstrating their preparedness, clarity, and ability to respond, they also served as a central resource for up-to-date and trustworthy information for people through their ongoing, informative communications.</p>
<h4>Humanity</h4>
<p>Humanity describes the values and resolve that demonstrate commitment to others’ interests, well-being, and individuality. This is the need to show that the government genuinely cares for its constituents’ experiences and well-being by demonstrating empathy, connection, and kindness. For instance, Dr. Stone encouraged and facilitated employees getting to know him beyond their titles and degrees. His openness and authenticity allowed employees to show the same—sending him personal messages about what was happening in their lives. They shared a connection while never wavering from the agency’s mission to save lives.</p>
<p>Sometimes empathy and fairness in communication come from a leader’s or organization’s ability to accept and acknowledge wrongdoing from the past. In February 2019, the city of Edmonton in Canada got a new police chief—Dale McFee. The Edmonton Police Service (EPS) had a history of concerns from members of the lesbian, gay, bisexual, transsexual, queer, and two-spirit (LGBTQ2S+) community going back decades. In May 2019, Chief McFee, in front of a packed atrium of members of the LGBTQ2S+ community, police officers, politicians, and other dignitaries, made a public apology to the community.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-9" href="#endnote-9">9</a></sup> “To the members of the lesbian, gay, bisexual, trans, queer, and two-spirit community—both across the public and within the service,” said Chief Mcfee, “on behalf of the Edmonton Police Service, I am sorry and we are sorry.”<sup><a id="endnote-sup-10" href="#endnote-10">10</a></sup></p>
<p>The chief’s message was clear: The department cannot change the past, but it can acknowledge, apologize, empathize, and build pathways for a better future.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-11" href="#endnote-11">11</a></sup> The message was direct, naming and acknowledging the emotional realities, not just changes to policies and processes.</p>
<h4>Integrity</h4>
<p>Integrity outlines the standards and norms that are consistently expected for relevant interactions. It signals that leaders will follow ethical standards when making decisions and openly share information, motives, and choices (wherever required and possible) related to policy, budget, and program decisions in a straightforward language. This was especially important because decisions and guidance shifted throughout the pandemic as more information was discovered. In some messages, Dr. Stone outlined the allocation model for vaccines or how a major decision was made. This allowed employees not just to see the end product but to understand the different implications and considerations that went into it. He was frank that these were hard choices that did not always make everyone, including him, happy.</p>
<p>In October–November 2020, El Paso, Texas, was in the middle of a brutal COVID-19 wave, with the city having the highest coronavirus infection rates in the country. With the arrival of a new mayor in January 2021, who himself had lost his mother and brother during the second wave, the administration decided to overhaul its communication strategy.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-12" href="#endnote-12">12</a></sup></p>
<p>The new mayor and his administration wanted cooperation from constituents to rein in the infection rate in the city. Beyond talking directly to residents, the city also created a COVID-19 dashboard, allowing the leadership team to be transparent and base its message on a single source of information. The dashboard was made public-facing to allow people to check information and build trust in the city’s COVID-19 response on the ground. The efforts paid off with El Paso becoming the first city with 81% of the population above five years of age fully vaccinated by May 2022.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-13" href="#endnote-13">13</a></sup></p>
<p>By baking in the three elements of trust in communication, governments can create and foster an environment in which organizations and leaders are trusted and messages are believed. However, government leaders also face the challenge of choosing the right tools, practices, and platforms to reach their constituents.</p>
<h3><a id="to-life"></a>Bringing it to life</h3>
<p>While both audiences and communicators may be more prepared for the pandemic today than two years ago, the next challenge for executives will be different. Strategies that focus on trust can be adapted to different situations and contexts. The work of a cross-functional communication team is to leverage approaches from multiple disciplines to address the trust deficit. One of the key advantages of trust is that it does not necessitate the agreement of all stakeholders. Trust doesn’t reflect confidence in an individual action, outcome, or response but the ability to navigate uncertainty because of a relationship.</p>
<p>Our perception of any content has emotional and neurochemical roots in our beliefs about the people and ideas surrounding or generating that content.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-14" href="#endnote-14">14</a></sup> In practice, this means that by understanding the psychology of trauma and stress, leaders can understand their stakeholder’s emotional landscape. Stress changes our perception at a chemical level and can impact our understanding of everything from words and images to team members and our environment.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-15" href="#endnote-15">15</a></sup> Several psychological approaches underline how the level of distress in our bodies can change how we hear and intake information even when it’s right in front of us.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-16" href="#endnote-16">16</a></sup> Adding behavioral health professionals to communication teams can change the tools and approaches they have at their disposal.</p>
<p>The following examples are not exhaustive communications plans but they show how responses might change when viewed through the lens of building trust. While crises can exacerbate the need for trust, it is better to be building it constantly. If leaders maintain authenticity and connection in good times, stakeholders may be more prepared to trust you when challenges arise. A steady state communication team can engage in many of these practices today even without a dedicated rapid response capability, but when the headlines focus on you, and you have everyone from journalists to unions waiting for your statement, it takes a specialized team.</p>

</div>

    

</div>

    <div id="cgiWrapperp2">
        <section id="applyingTheory">
            <div class="container article-width">
                <div id="viewCard" class="card-deck">
                    <div class="view-card-desktop">
                        <div class="imgCards">
                            <div class="row">
                                <div class="col-lg-6 imgCard card h-100" data-id="1" data-title="National demonstrations" tab-index="0" data-analytics-label="apply-the-theory:national-demonstrations-open-popup">
                                    <img src="https://www2.deloitte.com/content/dam/insights/us/USI-dev/2022/august/cgi-comms/assets/card-img1.png" class="img-fluid navCard h-100" alt="picture of a bird feeding on seeds on top of a human hand with data chart in background">
                                    <h1 class="card-title-mobile d-lg-none">National demonstrations</h1>
                                </div>
                                <div class="col-lg-6 imgCard card h-100" data-id="2" data-title="Employee deaths" tab-index="0" data-analytics-label="apply-the-theory:employee-deaths-open-popup">
                                    <img src="https://www2.deloitte.com/content/dam/insights/us/USI-dev/2022/august/cgi-comms/assets/card-img2.png" class="img-fluid navCard h-100" alt="Picture of a woman walking with a suitcase in front of a glass window">
                                    <h1 class="card-title-mobile d-lg-none">Employee deaths</h1>
                                </div>
                            </div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="imgCards">
                            <div class="row">
                                <div class="col-lg-6 imgCard card h-100" data-id="3" data-title="Fraud or abuse" tab-index="0" data-analytics-label="apply-the-theory:fraud-or-abuse-open-popup">
                                    <img src="https://www2.deloitte.com/content/dam/insights/us/USI-dev/2022/august/cgi-comms/assets/card-img3.png" class="img-fluid navCard h-100" alt="Picture of a human enjoying the nature">
                                    <h1 class="card-title-mobile d-lg-none">Fraud or abuse</h1>
                                </div>
                                <div class="col-lg-6 imgCard card h-100" data-id="4" data-title="Unknowable answer" tab-index="0" data-analytics-label="apply-the-theory:unknowable-answer-abuse-open-popup">
                                    <img src="https://www2.deloitte.com/content/dam/insights/us/USI-dev/2022/august/cgi-comms/assets/card-img4.png" class="img-fluid navCard h-100" alt="Picture of a women dancing">
                                    <h1 class="card-title-mobile d-lg-none">Unknowable answer</h1>
                                </div>
                            </div>
                        </div>
                    </div>
                </div>
                <div class="view-card-mobile">
                    <div class="cmp-container-width" id="trends-list">
                        <div id="threebox-container" class="threebox-container">
                            <div class="threebox-row row">
                                <div class="col-md-12 col-12 box-col p-0">
                                    <div class="box-body" data-modal="1">
                                        <h5 class="box-title">National demonstrations</h5>
                                        <div class="box-in">
                                            <p class="pop-title">Crisis scenario</p>
                                            <div class="accordian-content">
                                                <p>
                                                    A series of events has ignited an ongoing conversation about social injustices. National demonstrations grow around the issue and your employees
                                                    have written a letter to the leadership demanding more proactive action from the agency.
                                                </p>
                                            </div>
                                            <p class="pop-title">Response</p>

                                            <div class="accordian-content">
                                                <p>
                                                    Social license to operate is no longer a “nice to have” and organizations and leaders will struggle to succeed if they cannot speak well to
                                                    diversity, equity, and inclusion topics broadly and where their agency’s culture is specifically. First, resist becoming defensive and read the
                                                    letter. There may be suggestions that are practical and helpful; if so, ask your team to assess them for possible legal, financial, or operational
                                                    implications. For suggestions that are not implementable, listen to and affirm the emotions and needs driving the request, invite discussion and
                                                    disagreement directly in a townhall or an open forum, recognize where the organization has strengths and weaknesses, name specific ways that the
                                                    leaders are looking at this, and provide a clear date or timeline for additional information. These issues are large and multifaceted with many
                                                    differing voices and priorities. Don’t oversimplify, but don’t avoid hard truths. Remember, an angry email to a leader disagreeing passionately
                                                    shows much more trust than a quiet flow of resignations.
                                                </p>
                                                <p class="text-bottom">
                                                    This response is built on the conflict resolution model of LARA(I)—Listen, Affirm, Respond, Add Information, Inquire.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-17" href="#endnote-17">17</a></sup>
                                                </p>
                                            </div>
                                            <div class="mobile-image">
                                                <img src="https://www2.deloitte.com/content/dam/insights/us/USI-dev/2022/august/cgi-comms/assets/card-img1.png" class="img-fluid navCard h-100 w-100" alt="picture of a bird feeding on seeds on top of a human hand with data chart in background">
                                            </div>
                                        </div>
                                    </div>
                                </div>
                                <div class="col-md-12 col-12 box-col p-0">
                                    <div class="box-body" data-modal="2">
                                        <h5 class="box-title">Employee deaths</h5>
                                        <div class="box-in">
                                            <p class="pop-title">Crisis scenario</p>
                                            <div class="accordian-content">
                                                <p>
                                                    An accident at a government warehouse results in the death of three employees and one contractor. Within 24 hours, questions circulate about if they
                                                    were adequately protected and investigations into the incident are ongoing. Congressional leaders are reaching out.
                                                </p>
                                            </div>
                                            <p class="pop-title">Response</p>

                                            <div class="accordian-content">
                                                <p>
                                                    In the first hours after a tragedy, a leader often has more questions than answers as teams on the ground ensure safety and work with local
                                                    authorities. However, organizations cannot wait and allow their employees to hear narratives on the news or through informal channels first. Delays
                                                    in communication leave a massive gap for rumors and mistrust to form. Send a message to employees as soon as possible acknowledging the event and
                                                    when you will provide another update. Build an opportunity to be on video or live, in-person wherever possible; emotion generally translates much
                                                    better if your audience can see you. Share what you felt upon hearing the news and what steps you’re taking. Recognize that for some, this loss is
                                                    very personal. Commit to transparency and be clear about when more information should be available. Share mental health, HR, and other support
                                                    resources for employees and consider sending the most senior leader possible to the site to meet with close colleagues.
                                                </p>
                                                <p class="text-bottom">
                                                    This response is built on the research showing how to maintain relationships and repair them after trust is challenged. The more connected we feel
                                                    to someone, the more likely we are to contextualize accidents as unintentional or mistakes; the less we are connected, the more likely we are to
                                                    attribute them to malintent or disregard.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-18" href="#endnote-18">18</a></sup>
                                                </p>
                                            </div>
                                            <div class="mobile-image">
                                                <img src="https://www2.deloitte.com/content/dam/insights/us/USI-dev/2022/august/cgi-comms/assets/card-img2.png" class="img-fluid navCard h-100 w-100" alt="picture of a bird feeding on seeds on top of a human hand with data chart in background">
                                            </div>
                                        </div>
                                    </div>
                                </div>
                                <div class="col-md-12 col-12 box-col p-0">
                                    <div class="box-body" data-modal="3">
                                        <h5 class="box-title">Fraud or abuse</h5>
                                        <div class="box-in">
                                            <p class="pop-title">Crisis scenario</p>
                                            <div class="accordian-content">
                                                <p>
                                                    An Inspector General (IG) report comes out about financial mismanagement by a senior leader. The leader resigns and the organization is in the
                                                    process of investigating the impacts of the financial mismanagement. A news story openly wonders if the issues are systemic.
                                                </p>
                                            </div>
                                            <p class="pop-title">Response</p>

                                            <div class="accordian-content">
                                                <p>
                                                    Engage with your mid-level management. This is a critical stakeholder group that often has enough visibility to see and hear about senior-level
                                                    issues and decisions, and also has more direct relationships with frontline staff. Ask that they open a discussion at their next team meeting about
                                                    the IG report and article directly. Share what you can about what is known and unknown, including about the process and what will happen next.
                                                    Explain how it may or may not relate to their department and ask them if they agree with that assessment. For example, the accounting department may
                                                    be deeply involved while the engineering department may not be. However, asking your mid-level management for their thoughts can signal that you
                                                    trust them, even in this moment. Provide clear drafted responses to questions and language about how the actions don’t reflect what the agency
                                                    stands for. Identify points of contact for future questions and emphasize that you are proud of their work irrespective of what is being said in the
                                                    media.
                                                </p>
                                                <p>
                                                    If the culture of the organization is already tense or concerns about employee confidence are serious, the executive leader can spend five minutes
                                                    in as many existing team meetings as possible to share their confidence and show their commitment. Even if this adds up to hours of additional
                                                    meetings, it will be well worth the time.
                                                </p>
                                                <p class="text-bottom">
                                                    This response is built on the research documenting the power of existing social networks and connections. Senior leaders can “borrow” the
                                                    credibility of mid-level leaders who are more directly connected to front-line employees and go to employees in the places where they are accessing
                                                    information already.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-19" href="#endnote-19">19</a></sup> (Note: This is usually not email.) Business Insider reported in
                                                    their study on influencers that “As a general rule, targeted reach, cost-effectiveness, engagement, authenticity, and accessibility all go up as
                                                    follower count goes down.”<sup><a id="endnote-sup-20" href="#endnote-20">20</a></sup> So get to a smaller group level where trust is often
                                                    strongest.
                                                </p>
                                            </div>
                                            <div class="mobile-image">
                                                <img src="https://www2.deloitte.com/content/dam/insights/us/USI-dev/2022/august/cgi-comms/assets/card-img3.png" class="img-fluid navCard h-100 w-100" alt="picture of a bird feeding on seeds on top of a human hand with data chart in background">
                                            </div>
                                        </div>
                                    </div>
                                </div>
                                <div class="col-md-12 col-12 box-col p-0">
                                    <div class="box-body" data-modal="4">
                                        <h5 class="box-title">Unknowable answer</h5>
                                        <div class="box-in">
                                            <p class="pop-title">Crisis scenario</p>
                                            <div class="accordian-content">
                                                <p>
                                                    The country continues to struggle with the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. Many restrictions have been lifted and your team announced two weeks ago that
                                                    it’s planning a return-to-work transition in the next few months. Cases have risen steadily since that point. Uncertainty is palpable, and your
                                                    management team has made it clear that employees are worried. Return to work may not be possible at this time.
                                                </p>
                                            </div>
                                            <p class="pop-title">Response</p>

                                            <div class="accordian-content">
                                                <p>
                                                    Set up an ongoing channel of direct communication with your employees as soon as you can. This could be weekly or biweekly live webcasts or regular
                                                    video messages among others. Allow participants to send in questions and provide concrete answers on what you know now and when you will know more.
                                                    Address rumors directly in a dedicated session where people can hear what they may have heard from a colleague directly confirmed to discredited.
                                                    Give direct examples of a common employee experience and how it might change due to a policy. For questions that you cannot answer yet, be
                                                    transparent about how the decision will be made, what options exist, and what key metrics you’re looking at to inform your choices. Continue with a
                                                    regular cadence throughout the period of uncertainty, even if this means months.
                                                </p>
                                                <p class="text-bottom">
                                                    This response is built on ideas of schema. Schema are the frameworks by which we analyze the world and our environment.
                                                    <sup><a id="endnote-sup-21" href="#endnote-21">21</a></sup> When something new happens, our brains compare it to our existing schema to try to
                                                    derive meaning and assess what’s needed. By proactively shaping the conversation before rumors have spread too far, you are able to shape the lens
                                                    through which employees view new events rather than playing catch up to the narratives formed by others.
                                                </p>
                                            </div>
                                            <div class="mobile-image">
                                                <img src="https://www2.deloitte.com/content/dam/insights/us/USI-dev/2022/august/cgi-comms/assets/card-img4.png" class="img-fluid navCard h-100 w-100" alt="picture of a bird feeding on seeds on top of a human hand with data chart in background">
                                            </div>
                                        </div>
                                    </div>
                                </div>
                            </div>
                        </div>
                    </div>
                </div>
            </div>
        </section>
        <section>

                                            </div>
                                        </div>
                                        <div class="col-lg-3 pop-text-right popup-element animate__fadeInLeft">
                                            <p class="pop-right">
                                                This response is built on the research documenting the power of existing social networks and connections. Senior leaders can “borrow” the credibility of
                                                mid-level leaders who are more directly connected to front-line employees and go to employees in the places where they are accessing information
                                                already.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-19" href="#endnote-19">19</a></sup> (Note: This is usually not email.) Business Insider reported in their study on
                                                influencers that “As a general rule, targeted reach, cost-effectiveness, engagement, authenticity, and accessibility all go up as follower count goes
                                                down.”<sup><a id="endnote-sup-20" href="#endnote-20">20</a></sup> So get to a smaller group level where trust is often strongest.
                                            </p>
                                        </div>
                                    </div>
                                </div>
                            </div>
                            <div class="col-lg-12 indicator">
                                <div class="indicatorRow">
                                    <div class="square-indicator s1" data-id="1" data-analytics-label="indicator:open-national-demonstrations-popup" tab-index="0" data-toggle="tooltip" data-placement="top"></div>
                                    <div class="square-indicator s2" data-id="2" data-analytics-label="indicator:open-employee-deaths-popup" tab-index="0" data-toggle="tooltip" data-placement="top"></div>
                                </div>

                        <div class="pop-exit" data-analytics-label="fraud-or-abuse:close-popup" data-id="3" data-toggle="tooltip" data-placement="bottom" title="" data-original-title="Close" tabindex="0" role="button" arial-label="close button" aria-describedby="tooltip343275">
                            <div class="menu-icon-tooltip">

                            </div>

                        </div>
                    </div>
                </div>

                <div class="popWrap" id="dpop4">
                    <div class="popup-container pop-desktop">
                        <!-- <div class="cmp-container-width"> -->
                        <div>
                            <div class="col-12 d-flex">
                                <div class="img-overlay-container overlay-4" data-id="4">
                                    <div class="filter-btn col-12">
                                        <a class="filter-btn-1 active btn mr-3" data-analytics-label="unknowable-answer:crisis-scenario-filter" data-overlay="4" tabindex="0" role="button">
                                            CRISIS SCENARIO
                                        </a>
                                        <a class="filter-btn-2 btn" data-analytics-label="unknowable-answer:response-filter" data-overlay="4" tabindex="0" role="button"> RESPONSE </a>
                                    </div>
                                    <div class="d-flex crisis">
                                        <div class="col-lg-6 overlay-text popup-element animate__fadeInLeft">
                                            <h2 class="pop-title">CRISIS SCENARIO</h2>
                                            <h1 class="pop-heading tile">Unknowable answer</h1>
                                            <p class="pop-desc">
                                                The country continues to struggle with the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. Many restrictions have been lifted and your team announced two weeks ago that it’s
                                                planning a return-to-work transition in the next few months. Cases have risen steadily since that point. Uncertainty is palpable, and your management
                                                team has made it clear that employees are worried. Return to work may not be possible at this time.
                                            </p>
                                        </div>
                                        <div class="col-lg-6 pop-img popup-element animate__fadeInLeft">
                                            <img src="https://www2.deloitte.com/content/dam/insights/us/USI-dev/2022/august/cgi-comms/assets/pop-up-img4.png" class="img-fluid" alt="Picture of a women dancing">
                                        </div>
                                    </div>
                                    <div class="d-none response">
                                        <div class="col-lg-9 overlay-text-right popup-element animate__fadeInLeft border-white">
                                            <div class="text-wrapper">
                                                <h2 class="pop-title">Response</h2>
                                                <h1 class="pop-heading">Unknowable answer</h1>
                                                <p class="pop-desc" style="padding-bottom: 100px">
                                                    Set up an ongoing channel of direct communication with your employees as soon as you can. This could be weekly or biweekly live webcasts or regular
                                                    video messages among others. Allow participants to send in questions and provide concrete answers on what you know now and when you will know more.
                                                    Address rumors directly in a dedicated session where people can hear what they may have heard from a colleague directly confirmed to discredited.
                                                    Give direct examples of a common employee experience and how it might change due to a policy. For questions that you cannot answer yet, be
                                                    transparent about how the decision will be made, what options exist, and what key metrics you’re looking at to inform your choices. Continue with a
                                                    regular cadence throughout the period of uncertainty, even if this means months.
                                                </p>
                                            </div>
                                        </div>
                                        <div class="col-lg-3 pop-text-right popup-element animate__fadeInLeft">
                                            <p class="pop-right">
                                                This response is built on ideas of schema. Schema are the frameworks by which we analyze the world and our environment.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-21" href="#endnote-21">21</a></sup>
                                                When something new happens, our brains compare it to our existing schema to try to derive meaning and assess what’s needed. By proactively shaping the
                                                conversation before rumors have spread too far, you are able to shape the lens through which employees view new events rather than playing catch up to
                                                the narratives formed by others.
                                            </p>
                                        </div>
                                    </div>
                                </div>
                            </div>

                                </div>

    <script>
        $(document).on("click", "#cgiWrapperp2 .imgCard", function (event) {
            var no = $(this).attr("data-id");
            var noNew = no == 4 ? (noNew = 1) : (noNew = parseInt(no) + 1);
            $("#cgiWrapperp2 .square-indicator").removeAttr("data-original-title");
            $("#cgiWrapperp2 .popWrap").css("display", "none");
            $("#cgiWrapperp2 #dpop" + no + " .pop-mobile").css("display", "block");
            $("#cgiWrapperp2 .square-indicator").removeClass("active square-animate");
            $("#cgiWrapperp2 .imgCards").css("display", "none");
            $("#cgiWrapperp2 .overlay-" + no + " .crisis")
                .removeClass("d-none")
                .addClass("d-flex");
            $("#cgiWrapperp2 .overlay-" + no + " .response")
                .addClass("d-none")
                .removeClass("d-flex");
            $("#cgiWrapperp2 .overlay-" + no + " .filter-btn-1").addClass("active");
            $("#cgiWrapperp2 .overlayWrapper").css("display", "block");
            $("#cgiWrapperp2 .popup-element").addClass("animate__animated");
            // $(".popWrap").addClass("d-none");
            $("#cgiWrapperp2 #dpop" + no).css("display", "block");
            $("#cgiWrapperp2 .square-indicator[data-id=" + no + "]").addClass("active");
            $("#cgiWrapperp2 .square-indicator[data-id=" + noNew + "]").addClass("square-animate");
            setTimeout(function () {
                var tooltiptext = $("#cgiWrapperp2 #dpop" + no)
                    .find(".pop-desktop .pop-heading.tile")
                    .text();
                $("#cgiWrapperp2 .square-indicator.s" + no + ".active").attr("data-original-title", tooltiptext);
            }, 200);
            setTimeout(function () {
                $("#cgiWrapperp2 .square-indicator[data-id=" + noNew + "]").removeClass("square-animate");
            }, 8000);
            smoothScrollTo("#viewCard");
        });

        $("#cgiWrapperp2 .pop-exit").click(function (event) {
            var no = $(this).attr("data-id");
            $("#cgiWrapperp2 .popup-element").removeClass("animate__animated");
            $("#cgiWrapperp2 .overlayWrapper").fadeOut(500).css("display", "none");
            $("#cgiWrapperp2 .imgCards").fadeIn(1000).css("display", "block");
            $("#cgiWrapperp2 #dpop" + no)
                .fadeOut(500)
                .css("display", "none");
            $("#cgiWrapperp2 .square-indicator").removeClass("active square-animate");
            $("#cgiWrapperp2 .filter-btn-2").removeClass("active");
            smoothScrollTo("#viewCard");
        });

        $("#cgiWrapperp2 .close-detailPopup").click(function (event) {
            var no = $(this).attr("data-id");
            $("#cgiWrapperp2 #dpop" + no + " .pop-mobile")
                .fadeIn(1000)
                .css("display", "none");
            $("#cgiWrapperp2 .imgCards").fadeIn(1000).css("display", "block");
            smoothScrollTo("#viewCard");
        });

        $("#cgiWrapperp2 .accordian-tab").click(function (event) {
            $(this).parent().hasClass("active") ? $($(this).parent()[0]).removeClass("active") : $($(this).parent()[0]).addClass("active");

            smoothScrollTo("#viewCard");
        });

        $(document).on("click", "#cgiWrapperp2 .square-indicator", function (event) {
            $("#cgiWrapperp2 .square-indicator").removeAttr("data-original-title");
            $("#cgiWrapperp2 .popWrap").css("display", "none");
            $("#cgiWrapperp2 .popup-element").removeClass("animate__animated");
            $("#cgiWrapperp2 .square-indicator").removeClass("active square-animate");
            var no = $(this).attr("data-id");
            var noNew = no == 4 ? (noNew = 1) : (noNew = parseInt(no) + 1);
            $("#cgiWrapperp2 .overlay-" + no + " .filter-btn-1").addClass("active");
            $("#cgiWrapperp2 .filter-btn-2").removeClass("active");
            $("#cgiWrapperp2 #dpop" + no).css("display", "block");
            $("#cgiWrapperp2 .popup-element").addClass("animate__animated");
            $("#cgiWrapperp2 .square-indicator[data-id=" + no + "]").addClass("active");
            setTimeout(function () {
                var tooltiptext = $("#cgiWrapperp2 #dpop" + no)
                    .find(".pop-desktop .pop-heading.tile")
                    .text();
                $("#cgiWrapperp2 .square-indicator.s" + no + ".active").attr("data-original-title", tooltiptext);
            }, 200);
            $("#cgiWrapperp2 .square-indicator[data-id=" + noNew + "]").addClass("square-animate");
            $("#cgiWrapperp2 .overlay-" + no + " .crisis")
                .removeClass("d-none")
                .addClass("d-flex");
            $("#cgiWrapperp2 .overlay-" + no + " .response")
                .addClass("d-none")
                .removeClass("d-flex");
            setTimeout(function () {
                $("#cgiWrapperp2 .square-indicator[data-id=" + noNew + "]").removeClass("square-animate");
            }, 8000);
            setTimeout(function () {
                imageUrl = "https://www2.deloitte.com/content/dam/insights/us/USI-dev/2022/august/cgi-comms/assets/bg-desktop.png";
                $("#cgiWrapperp2 .overlayWrapper")

        });

        $("#cgiWrapperp2 .img-overlay-container .filter-btn-2").click(function (event) {
            var no = $(this).attr("data-overlay");

            $(this).addClass("active");
            $("#cgiWrapperp2 .overlay-" + no + " .response")
                .removeClass("d-none")

            $("#cgiWrapperp2 .overlay-" + no + " .crisis")

            setTimeout(function () {

                $("#cgiWrapperp2 .overlayWrapper")
                    .css("background-image", "url(" + imageUrl + ")")

                // .addClass("animate__animated animate__slower")

        function smoothScrollTo(hash) {
            if ($(window).width() < 991) {
                $("html, body").animate(
                    {
                        scrollTop: $(hash).offset().top - 55,
                    },
                    750
                );
            } else {
                $("html, body").animate(
                    {
                        scrollTop: $(hash).offset().top - 40,
                    },
                    750
                );
            }
            // if (history.pushState) {
            //     history.pushState(null, null, hash);
            // }
        }
        $(document).ready(function () {
            $(window).innerWidth() >= 1024
                ? $(".box-body").click(function (event) {
                      var modal = $(this).attr("data-modal"),
                          c = 1;
                      $(".threebox-row").addClass("animate__animated animate__fadeOutLeft animate__slow"),
                          setTimeout(function () {
                              openTrendsModal(modal);
                          }, 750),
                          setTimeout(function () {
                              $(".threebox-container").addClass("d-none");
                          }, 1e3);
                  })
                : $(".box-title").click(function (event) {
                      $(this).parent(".box-body").toggleClass("box-open"), $(this).parent(".box-body").children(".box-in").slideToggle("slow");
                  });
        });

        $(".box-body .box-title").on("click", function (e) {
            // var text = $(this).attr("data-analytics-label");
            var text = $(this).text();
            var toggle = $(".box-body").hasClass("box-open");
            console.log(toggle);
            var label = toggle ? "close" : "open";
            // var label = "true" == $(this).attr("aria-expanded") ? "close" : "open";
            var modText = text
                .replace(/[^a-zA-Z-: ]/g, "")
                .trim()
                .replace(/\s+/g, "-")
                .toLowerCase()
                .split(0, 4);
            showAnalytics(modText + ":" + label + "-accordion", e);
        });
        $(document).ready(function () {
            $("sup a, a[href^='#'], .endnotes sup a, .endnotes a[href^='#']").click(function (e) {
                e.preventDefault();
                var endnoteOffset, subnavHeight;
                var mainHeaderHeight = 0;
                var cookieHeight = 0;
                var isScrollBottomtoTop = false;
                var tabPanelID = $(this).attr("href");
                var tabPanelIDTop = $(tabPanelID).offset().top - 40;
                var accordionPanel = $(".cmp-accordion__item").find(tabPanelID);
                cookieHeight = cookieHeight + $(".cookie-container").outerHeight(true);
                var accordionPanelLabel = accordionPanel.parents(".cmp-accordion__item");
                var accordionPanelTab = accordionPanel.parents(".cmp-accordion__panel");
                var isAccordionExpanded = accordionPanelTab.hasClass("cmp-accordion__panel--expanded");
                if (!isAccordionExpanded) {
                    accordionPanelLabel.attr("data-cmp-expanded", "");
                    accordionPanelLabel.children(".cmp-accordion__header").find(".cmp-accordion__button").addClass("cmp-accordion__button--expanded").attr("aria-expanded", "true");
                    accordionPanelTab.addClass("cmp-accordion__panel--expanded").removeClass("cmp-accordion__panel--hidden").attr("aria-hidden", false);
                }
                //checkis sticky header or cookie alert are present
                subnavHeight = $(".subnav-fixed").outerHeight();
                var isCookiebarVisible =
                    ($(".optanon-alert-box-wrapper").length && $(".optanon-alert-box-wrapper").is(":visible")) || ($(".cookie-container").length && $(".cookie-container").is(":visible"));
                var isStickyheaderVisible = $(".cmp-sticky-header") && $(".cmp-sticky-header").is(":visible");
                var media = window.matchMedia("(max-width:767px)");
                if (media.matches) {
                    // ismainheaderVisible = ($('#header') && $('#header').is(":visible"));
                    if ($("#header").css("position") == "relative") {
                        mainHeaderHeight = 0;
                    } else {
                        mainHeaderHeight = $("#header").height();
                    }
                    //subnavheight is not needed in mobile as it is stacked to bottom
                    subnavHeight = 0;
                    //targeting href value to find the direction of scroll
                    var refValue = tabPanelID.toString();
                    isScrollBottomtoTop = refValue.includes("#endnote-sup");
                }
                var isCookieandHeaderVisible = isCookiebarVisible && isStickyheaderVisible;

                var stickybarHeight = $(".cmp-sticky-header").outerHeight();
                //if cookie banner is present we need to reduce the offset value
                if (isCookiebarVisible || isCookieandHeaderVisible) {
                    var OTCookieBannerHeight = $(".optanon-alert-box-wrapper").outerHeight();
                    cookieHeight = cookieHeight + OTCookieBannerHeight;
                    //adding some extra offset when scroll from bottom
                    if (isScrollBottomtoTop) {
                        endnoteOffset = tabPanelIDTop - stickybarHeight - subnavHeight - cookieHeight - mainHeaderHeight - 170 + "px";
                    } else {
                        endnoteOffset = tabPanelIDTop - stickybarHeight - subnavHeight - cookieHeight - mainHeaderHeight + "px";
                    }
                }
                //check if sticky header is there, if yes reduce the offset value
                else if (isStickyheaderVisible) {
                    if (isScrollBottomtoTop) {
                        endnoteOffset = tabPanelIDTop - stickybarHeight - subnavHeight - mainHeaderHeight - 270 + "px";
                    } else {
                        endnoteOffset = tabPanelIDTop - stickybarHeight - subnavHeight - mainHeaderHeight + "px";
                    }
                } else {
                    endnoteOffset = tabPanelIDTop + "px";
                }
                $("html, body").animate(
                    {
                        scrollTop: endnoteOffset,
                    },
                    "slow",
                    function () {
                        $(tabPanelID).focus();
                    }
                );
            });
            setTimeout(function () {
                $("#endnote-17,#endnote-18,#endnote-19,#endnote-20,#endnote-21").attr("href", "#cgiWrapperp2");
            }, 2000);
        });
    </script>

    <section id="applyingTheory">
        <div class="container">
            <div class="row">

                <!-- <p class="col-md-12 falseHeight">
                    Lorem Ipsum is simply dummy text of the printing and typesetting industry.
